expanded_description: Factoring by grouping is a technique used when a polynomial has four or more terms. By grouping terms with common factors, we can factor each group separately and then factor out a common binomial factor. This method is particularly useful for factoring cubic polynomials and for polynomials that don't have a common factor in all terms.

core_concept.principle:
To factor a polynomial by grouping:
1. Group terms that have a common factor (usually in pairs).
2. Factor out the GCF from each group.
3. If the resulting binomial factors are the same, factor out that common binomial.
4. Write the final answer as the product of the common binomial and the other factor.
core_concept.explanation: Think of factoring by grouping like organizing a team project. First, you put people into smaller groups (grouping). Each group works on their part (factoring each group). Then you notice that both groups produced something similar (a common binomial), so you combine their work. The result shows the overall structure of the original polynomial.

image.alt: Step-by-step visual of factoring by grouping: ax + ay + bx + by = a(x+y) + b(x+y) = (x+y)(a+b)
image.caption: Figure 11.2.1: The factoring by grouping process.

sections.introduction: Factoring by grouping is used when a polynomial has four or more terms and no single GCF for all terms.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 11.2.2: When to use factoring by grouping.

key_concept.definition: A polynomial like $ax + ay + bx + by$ has no common factor in all four terms, but the first two terms share $a$ and the last two share $b$. By grouping them as $(ax + ay) + (bx + by)$, we can factor each group: $a(x+y) + b(x+y)$. Then factor out the common binomial $(x+y)$ to get $(x+y)(a+b)$.
key_concept.context: This method works when the polynomial can be arranged so that each group has a common factor and the resulting binomial factors are identical.

worked_examples.title: Understanding the Grouping Pattern

image.caption: Figure 11.2.4: Show how to group each polynomial.

worked_examples.problem:
For each polynomial, show how to group the terms to prepare for factoring by grouping:
a) $x^3 + 2x^2 + 3x + 6$
b) $2x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 6$
c) $5x^3 + 10x^2 - 3x - 6$

step_by_step.explanation: Group first two and last two terms
Group first two and last two terms
Group first two and last two terms

worked_examples.concept_applied: Group terms in pairs that have common factors.

sections.introduction: After grouping, factor out the GCF from each group.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 11.2.6: Factor out the GCF from each group.

key_concept.definition: For each group, identify and factor out the greatest common factor of the terms in that group. This will leave a binomial (or other polynomial) inside parentheses. The goal is to have the same binomial appear in both groups after factoring.
key_concept.context: If the binomials after factoring are not the same, try rearranging the terms or grouping differently.

worked_examples.title: Factoring Each Group

image.caption: Figure 11.2.8: Factor each group after grouping.

worked_examples.problem:
For each polynomial from the previous example, factor each group:
a) $(x^3 + 2x^2) + (3x + 6)$
b) $(2x^3 - 3x^2) + (4x - 6)$
c) $(5x^3 + 10x^2) + (-3x - 6)$

step_by_step.explanation: First group: GCF $x^2$, gives $x^2(x + 2)$; second group: GCF $3$, gives $3(x + 2)$
First group: GCF $x^2$, gives $x^2(2x - 3)$; second group: GCF $2$, gives $2(2x - 3)$
First group: GCF $5x^2$, gives $5x^2(x + 2)$; second group: GCF $-3$, gives $-3(x + 2)$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Factor out the GCF from each group, aiming for matching binomials.

sections.introduction: Once both groups have a common binomial factor, factor that binomial out.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 11.2.10: Factor out the common binomial.

key_concept.definition: When you have an expression like $A \cdot B + C \cdot B$, where $B$ is the common binomial, factor out $B$ to get $B(A + C)$. For example, $x^2(x+2) + 3(x+2) = (x+2)(x^2 + 3)$.
key_concept.context: This is the reverse of the distributive property and completes the factoring process.

worked_examples.title: Factoring Out the Common Binomial
worked_examples.problem:
Factor out the common binomial to complete the factoring:
a) $x^2(x+2) + 3(x+2)$
b) $x^2(2x-3) + 2(2x-3)$
c) $5x^2(x+2) - 3(x+2)$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Factor out the binomial that appears in both terms.

process_flow.description: Group the polynomial into pairs that have common factors.
process_flow.mechanism: Look for pairs of terms that share a GCF.

process_flow.description: Factor out the GCF from each group.
process_flow.mechanism: Use GCF factoring on each group separately.

process_flow.description: Identify and factor out the binomial that appears in both terms.

image.alt: Summary of factoring out common binomial
image.caption: Figure 11.2.16: Common binomial summary.

sections.introduction: Now let's put all the steps together and factor polynomials completely by grouping.

key_concept.definition: Factoring by grouping involves all three steps: grouping, factoring each group, and factoring out the common binomial. Always check if the resulting factors can be factored further.
key_concept.context: Practice with complete examples helps solidify the process.

worked_examples.title: Complete Factoring by Grouping
worked_examples.concept_applied: Follow all three steps: group, factor groups, factor common binomial.

image.alt: Summary of complete factoring by grouping
image.caption: Figure 11.2.20: Complete grouping summary.

sections.introduction: Sometimes the terms need to be rearranged to make grouping work.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 11.2.21: Sometimes terms need to be reordered.

key_concept.definition: If the initial grouping doesn't yield a common binomial, try rearranging the terms. Polynomials are commutative for addition, so terms can be moved as long as their signs stay with them. For example, $x^3 + 3x + 2x^2 + 6$ can be regrouped as $(x^3 + 3x) + (2x^2 + 6)$.
key_concept.context: Rearranging is often necessary when the polynomial isn't written in an order conducive to grouping.

worked_examples.title: Rearranging for Grouping

image.caption: Figure 11.2.23: Factor each polynomial by first rearranging terms.

worked_examples.problem:
Factor each polynomial by grouping. You may need to rearrange terms first.
a) $x^3 + 2x + x^2 + 2$
b) $2x^3 + 6 + x^2 + 3x$
c) $3x^3 - 12 + 2x^2 - 8x$

step_by_step.calculation: Group: $(2x^3+x^2) + (3x+6) = x^2(2x+1) + 3(x+2)$ - binomials don't match! Try different grouping.
$2(x^3+3) + x(x+3)$ - no match. This polynomial might not factor by grouping.
Group: $(3x^3+2x^2) + (-8x-12) = x^2(3x+2) -4(2x+3)$ - binomials don't match. Try different grouping.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) $(x+1)(x^2+2)$, b) May not factor by simple grouping, c) May not factor by simple grouping
worked_examples.concept_applied: Sometimes rearranging helps, but not all polynomials factor by grouping.

image.alt: Summary of rearranging terms for grouping
image.caption: Figure 11.2.24: Rearranging terms summary.

sections.section_title: 11.2.6 Factoring by Grouping with Negative Signs
sections.introduction: Careful attention to signs is crucial when factoring by grouping, especially when negative signs are involved.

key_concept.definition: When grouping terms with negative signs, pay attention to the sign before each group. Factoring out a negative from a group will change the signs inside. For example, $x^3 - 2x^2 - 3x + 6$ can be grouped as $(x^3 - 2x^2) + (-3x + 6)$ or as $(x^3 - 2x^2) - (3x - 6)$.
key_concept.context: Choosing the right grouping can make the binomial factors match more easily.

worked_examples.title: Grouping with Negatives
worked_examples.problem:
Factor each polynomial by grouping, being careful with signs:
a) $x^3 - 3x^2 - 2x + 6$
b) $2x^3 - 4x^2 - 3x + 6$
c) $x^3 - 2x^2 - 4x + 8$

step_by_step.explanation: $x^2 - 4$ is a difference of squares and can factor further

worked_examples.concept_applied: When factoring a negative from a group, signs inside change.

image.alt: Summary of grouping with negative signs
image.caption: Figure 11.2.28: Negative signs summary.

sections.section_title: 11.2.7 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when factoring by grouping. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: Grouping terms that don't have a common factor.
characteristics: Pairing terms randomly without checking for common factors
Not ensuring each group has a GCF

examples.process: Error: Grouping $x^3 + 2x^2 + 3x + 6$ as $(x^3+3x) + (2x^2+6)$ actually works. Need a bad example: $(x^3+6) + (2x^2+3x)$ has no common factors
examples.explanation: Correct: Choose groupings where each pair has a common factor

classifications.value: Mistakes with signs when factoring out a negative from a group.

classifications.type: Forgetting to Check for Further Factoring
classifications.value: Stopping when one of the factors can be factored further.
characteristics: Leaving $x^2 - 4$ as is instead of factoring as $(x-2)(x+2)$

image.alt: Complete factoring vs stopping too soon
image.caption: Figure 11.2.31: Error - not factoring completely.

worked_examples.title: Correcting Grouping Errors
worked_examples.problem: A student factored $x^3 - 2x^2 - 3x + 6$ as $(x-2)(x^2+3)$. Is this correct?

step_by_step.calculation: This gives $+3x$, not $-3x$, so it's incorrect

worked_examples.concept_applied: Always check by multiplying back to verify.

image.alt: Summary table of common grouping errors and corrections
image.caption: Figure 11.2.33: Common errors summary.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to factor a variety of polynomials by grouping.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.concept_applied: Practice factoring by grouping with various polynomials.

summary: Factoring by grouping is a technique used for polynomials with four or more terms. The process involves: (1) grouping terms that have common factors, (2) factoring out the GCF from each group, and (3) factoring out the common binomial that results. The key is to arrange the terms so that after factoring each group, the same binomial appears. Sometimes terms need to be rearranged to achieve this. Careful attention to signs is crucial, especially when factoring out negatives from groups. After factoring by grouping, always check if any of the resulting factors can be factored further (like difference of squares). Factoring by grouping is essential for factoring cubic polynomials and for preparing polynomials for solving equations and simplifying rational expressions.

review_questions_image.alt: Comprehensive summary: grouping steps, factoring groups, common binomial, rearranging terms, handling negatives
review_questions_image.caption: Figure 11.2.36: Factoring by grouping summary.
